carousel_items: Can take a few days to start working.
Take Dexilant with or without food. It can work better for some people if it's taken 30 minutes before a meal.
Call your doctor if you have watery stools, stomach pain, or a fever because it could be a sign of a serious infection.
Dexilant can lower the amount of magnesium in your body. Initial and follow-up blood tests may be needed before starting Dexilant.

basics.benefits_moa: Dexilant is a proton pump inhibitor (PPI). It lowers the amount of acid in your stomach, treats heartburn, and heals ulcers.
basics.bottom_line: Dexilant is an effective medicine to treat heartburn and ulcers, but can be expensive.
downsides: Taking Dexilant in high doses or for longer than 1 year can increase the risk for bone fractures, especially if you already have osteoporosis (weak bones).
Many drugs can interact with Dexilant, so talk to your doctor or pharmacist before starting any new medicines.
There's no generic version available, so it can be expensive.

downsides_processed.orig: Taking Dexilant in high doses or for longer than 1 year can increase the risk for bone fractures, especially if you already have osteoporosis (weak bones).
Many drugs can interact with Dexilant, so talk to your doctor or pharmacist before starting any new medicines.
There's no generic version available, so it can be expensive.

upsides: Relieves heartburn symptoms and heals ulcers better than other stomach medicines, such as Pepcid, Tagamet, and Zantac.
Lasts longer than other similar stomach medicines. Most people take it once a day.
Your body won't develop a tolerance to Dexilant, so it'll work the same way as long as you need to keep taking it.
Once heartburn symptoms are treated, a low dose of Dexilant can be taken daily.

risks_warnings.title: Hiding possible cancer
risks_warnings.description: Heartburn and feelings of upset stomach can be warning signs of a more serious stomach problem or cancer. If you need to take Dexilant for 2 weeks or more go see a doctor. It's safest to get checked out to make sure you do not have a serious stomach condition.

description_processed.orig: Heartburn and feelings of upset stomach can be warning signs of a more serious stomach problem or cancer. If you need to take Dexilant for 2 weeks or more go see a doctor. It's safest to get checked out to make sure you do not have a serious stomach condition.

risks_warnings.title: Severe stomach inflammation (atrophic gastritis)
risks_warnings.description: Severe stomach inflammation (atrophic gastritis) has occasionally happened to people taking Dexilant.  It can lead to digestion trouble, low vitamin B12 levels, and anemia. It's more common if you have a stomach infection caused by the bacteria Helicobacter pylori. If you need to take Dexilant for 2 weeks or more go see a doctor. It's safest to get checked out to make sure you do not have a serious stomach condition.

risks_warnings.title: Severe diarrhea
risks_warnings.description: Using medications like Dexilant (proton pump inhibitors) can increase the chance of getting severe diarrhea.  This diarrhea is caused by an infection from a bacteria called clostridium difficle or C.Diff.  The infection is difficult to treat and can be life threatening. You are at a higher risk for C.Diff if you are currently or have recently been in a hospital.  You are also at higher risk if you are currently or have recenlty taken any antibiotic medication. If you develop significant diarrhea while taking Dexilant or after stopping it, let you doctor know right away.

risks_warnings.title: Broken bones
risks_warnings.description: There is an increased risk of developing weakened bones (osteoporosis) and broken bones (fractures) while taking medications like Dexilant (proton pump inhibitors).  It is believed that this happens because your stomach doesn't absorb calcium well while using this medication. Calcium is necessary for strong, healthy bones. In studies, people were more likely to get broken bones while using proton pump inhibitors when taking high doses and using them long-term (1 year or more). You are also at higher risk if you smoke or have other risk factors for osteoporosis.  The best way to prevent this side effect is to use the lowest dose of medication for the shortest period of time.  Taking a calcium supplement may or may not help prevent broken bones while using Dexilant.  However, if you need to take Dexilant long-term you should take a calcium supplement to be safe.  Be sure it's calcium citrate because it works the best when using a proton pump inhibitor.

risks_warnings.title: Low vitamin or mineral levels
risks_warnings.description: All proton pump inhibitor medications, including Dexilant, can cause low levels of blood magnesium or vitamin B12. This can happen with as little as 3 months of use but more commonly occurs after you've been using Dexilant for a year or more. Your doctor can do a blood test to see if you need to take a vitamin or mineral supplement.

carousel_items: Take 1 hour before a meal.
Don't chew or crush capsules; swallow them whole.
If you have trouble swallowing you can carefully open the capsules and sprinkle the inside pellets onto applesauce. Swallow the applesauce without chewing or crushing the pellets.
When using Nexium long-term, take a calcium citrate with vitamin D supplement daily to prevent bone loss. Be sure it's calcium citrate because it works the best when using a proton pump inhibitor.
Get a blood test for your magnesium level once a year; you may need a magnesium supplement while using Nexium.
Avoid drug interactions by telling your doctor all of the other medications or herbal supplements you take before starting Nexium.

clock.tip: Take on an empty stomach before breakfast.

basics.benefits_moa: Nexium is a proton pump inhibitor (PPI). It lowers the amount of acid in your stomach, treats heartburn, and heals ulcers.
basics.bottom_line: Nexium gives you long-lasting heartburn relief. But this purple pill ain't cheap! The generic forms of alternative drugs work just as well, and are usually less expensive.
downsides: Doesn't start working as fast as some other antacids like Tums, Rolaids, or Maalox.
Like with other proton pump inhibitors, long-term use can cause weak or broken bones.
Can cause low levels of magnesium in the blood. You might need to take a magnesium supplement if you use Nexium long-term.
Can be expensive. Other alternatives are usually cheaper than Nexium.
Can interact with other drugs so be sure your doctor knows all the medicine you're taking before starting Nexium.

downsides_processed.orig: Doesn't start working as fast as some other antacids like Tums, Rolaids, or Maalox.
Like with other proton pump inhibitors, long-term use can cause weak or broken bones.
Can cause low levels of magnesium in the blood. You might need to take a magnesium supplement if you use Nexium long-term.
Can be expensive. Other alternatives are usually cheaper than Nexium.
Can interact with other drugs so be sure your doctor knows all the medicine you're taking before starting Nexium.

upsides: Most people can take Nexium without any noticeable day-to-day side effects.
Nexium lasts longer than other types of antacids (like Zantac, Pepcid, or Tums), and you only need to take it once or twice a day.
You can take it in combination with a quick-acting antacid (like Maalox or Tums) if you need relief right away.
In studies it was better than a placebo (sugar pill) and as good as other proton pump inhibitors at treating heartburn.
Available as both a generic and over-the-counter option, so it's pretty affordable.

I wish I had known how hard it would be to stop taking Nexium. I've been on it for six years and I am entirely dependent on it. My stomach just can't get used to having that much acid in it again. But I haven't had one bad day on Nexium!

userStories.tip: Took Nexium for seven years, then found Omerprazole. Worked so well for two years that I cut the caplets in half two years ago. All's well so far. Have forgotten a few times but remember real quick, within two hours, discomfort.

I was having horrible acid reflux and was diagnosed with Barrett's rings in my esophagus 9 years ago. Since I started taking this simple drug, the acid reflux is completely gone and the ring growth has been arrested.

Skipping a dose or two does not seem to cause problems.   Occasional break-through heartburn easily fixed with Tums.  Even with a large copay it is cheaper if you get a prescription and have it filled at the pharmacy.

basics.benefits_moa: Pantoprazole is a proton pump inhibitor (PPI). It lowers the amount of acid in your stomach, treats heartburn, and heals ulcers.
basics.bottom_line: Pantoprazole gives you long-lasting heartburn relief. Choose the cheapest proton pump inhibitor because they all work equally well for heartburn.
downsides: Doesn't start working as fast as some other antacids like Tums, Rolaids, or Maalox.
Like with other proton pump inhibitors, long-term use can cause weak or broken bones.
Can cause low levels of magnesium in the blood. You might need to take a magnesium supplement if you use Pantoprazole long-term.
Can be expensive. Other alternatives are usually cheaper than Pantoprazole.
Less risk of drug interactions with Pantoprazole than with other proton pump inhibitors.

downsides_processed.orig: Doesn't start working as fast as some other antacids like Tums, Rolaids, or Maalox.
Like with other proton pump inhibitors, long-term use can cause weak or broken bones.
Can cause low levels of magnesium in the blood. You might need to take a magnesium supplement if you use Pantoprazole long-term.

upsides: Most people can take Pantoprazole without any noticeable day-to-day side effects.
Pantoprazole lasts longer than other types of antacids (like Zantac, Pepcid, or Tums), and you only need to take it once or twice a day.
You can take it in combination with a quick-acting antacid (like Maalox or Tums) if you need relief right away.
In studies it was better than a placebo (sugar pill) and as good as other proton pump inhibitors at treating heartburn.
Available as both a generic and over-the-counter option, so it's pretty affordable.

carousel_items_processed.orig: Take with or without food.
Swallow tablets whole; don't split, crush, or chew.
Take the oral suspension 30 minutes before a meal mixed only with applesauce or apple juice. Follow instructions carefully.

When using Pantoprazole long-term, take a calcium citrate with vitamin D supplement daily to prevent bone loss. Be sure it's calcium citrate because it works the best when using a proton pump inhibitor.
Get a blood test for your magnesium level once a year; you may need a magnesium supplement while using Pantoprazole.
Avoid drug interactions by telling your doctor all of the other medications or herbal supplements you take before starting Pantoprazole.

risks_warnings.title: Hiding possible cancer
risks_warnings.description: Heartburn and feelings of upset stomach can be warning signs of a more serious stomach problem or cancer. If you need to take Pantoprazole for 2 weeks or more go see a doctor. It's safest to get checked out to make sure you do not have a serious stomach condition.

description_processed.orig: Heartburn and feelings of upset stomach can be warning signs of a more serious stomach problem or cancer. If you need to take Pantoprazole for 2 weeks or more go see a doctor. It's safest to get checked out to make sure you do not have a serious stomach condition.

risks_warnings.title: Severe stomach inflammation (atrophic gastritis)
risks_warnings.description: Severe stomach inflammation (atrophic gastritis) has occasionally happened to people taking Pantoprazole.  It can lead to digestion trouble, low vitamin B12 levels, and anemia. It's more common if you have a stomach infection caused by the bacteria Helicobacter pylori. If you need to take Pantoprazole for 2 weeks or more go see a doctor. It's safest to get checked out to make sure you do not have a serious stomach condition.

risks_warnings.title: Broken bones
risks_warnings.description: There is an increased risk of developing weakened bones (osteoporosis) and broken bones (fractures) while taking medications like Pantoprazole (proton pump inhibitors).  It is believed that this happens because your stomach doesn't absorb calcium well while using this medication. Calcium is necessary for strong, healthy bones. In studies, people were more likely to get broken bones while using proton pump inhibitors when taking high doses and using them long-term (1 year or more). You are also at higher risk if you smoke or have other risk factors for osteoporosis.  The best way to prevent this side effect is to use the lowest dose of medication for the shortest period of time.  Taking a calcium supplement may or may not help prevent broken bones while using Pantoprazole.  However, if you need to take Pantoprazole long-term you should take a calcium supplement to be safe.  Be sure it's calcium citrate because it works the best when using a proton pump inhibitor.

risks_warnings.title: Low vitamin or mineral levels
risks_warnings.description: All proton pump inhibitor medications, including Pantoprazole, can cause low levels of blood magnesium or vitamin B12. This can happen with as little as 3 months of use but more commonly occurs after you've been using Pantoprazole for a year or more. Your doctor can do a blood test to see if you need to take a vitamin or mineral supplement.

risks_warnings.title: Stomach cancer
risks_warnings.description: In animal studies, long-term use of Pantoprazole caused rare types of stomach tumors. Since acid-reflux disease (commonly known as heartburn) can last for a long time some people may find that they need to take Pantoprazole for a long time as well.  It is unknown if the risk for stomach tumors is the same for people as it is for other animals.

basics.bottom_line: Prevacid gives you long-lasting heartburn relief and helps heal ulcers.
downsides: Doesn't start working as fast as some other antacids like Tums, Rolaids, or Maalox.
Depending on the condition you are treating, it can take one to two weeks to get the full effect.

risks_warnings.title: Severe diarrhea
risks_warnings.description: Using medications like Prevacid (proton pump inhibitors) can increase the chance of getting severe diarrhea.  This diarrhea is caused by an infection from a bacteria called clostridium difficle or C.Diff.  The infection is difficult to treat and can be life threatening. You are at a higher risk for C.Diff if you are currently or have recently been in a hospital.  You are also at higher risk if you are currently or have recently taken any antibiotic medication. If you develop significant diarrhea while taking Prevacid or after stopping it, let you doctor know right away.

basics.benefits_moa: Cimetidine is a type of antacid called an H2 blocker. It blocks the chemical histamine, which lowers acid production in your stomach. This treats heartburn and helps ulcers heal.
basics.bottom_line: Cimetidine works well for heartburn but may not last as long or start working as quickly as other antacids.
downsides: Other antacids like Maalox, Tums, or Rolaids often start to work more quickly than Cimetidine.
Medication like omeprazole (proton pump inhibitors) works better at healing and preventing stomach ulcers than medication like Cimetidine (H2 blockers).
Has more drug interactions than zantac and pepcid.

Although rare, Cimetidine can cause large breasts or impotence for men who need to use high doses for 6 months or more. It's reversible though and should go away when you stop or if you change medication.

Available as both a generic and over-the-counter option, so it's pretty affordable.

risks_warnings.title: Confusion
risks_warnings.description: Cimetidine can cause states of intense confusion. This is usually reversible when you stop taking Cimetidine. If you have kidney problems, you may need a different dose to prevent this increased risk for side effects.  However, stopping Cimetidine completely may be necessary.

risks_warnings.title: Allergic reaction
risks_warnings.description: Cimetidine can cause an allergic reaction.  The reaction might cause swelling of the throat, face, lips or tongue, difficulty breathing, or rash. If this happens to you stop taking Cimetidine and get medical help right away. Do not take Cimetidine if you have ever had an allergic reaction to similar medications like zantac or tagamet.

If you've been having heartburn for 3 months or more, talk to your doctor before taking Zegerid. Get a check-up to make sure you aren't having a more serious stomach problem.
Talk to your doctor if you're still having heartburn after two weeks of use. Don't keep taking Zegerid; get checked-out first.

risks_warnings.title: Severe stomach inflammation (atrophic gastritis)
risks_warnings.description: Severe stomach inflammation (atrophic gastritis) has occasionally happened to people taking Zegerid.  It can lead to digestion trouble, low vitamin B12 levels, and anemia. It's more common if you have a stomach infection caused by the bacteria Helicobacter pylori. If you need to take Zegerid for 2 weeks or more go see a doctor. It's safest to get checked out to make sure you do not have a serious stomach condition.

risks_warnings.title: Severe diarrhea
risks_warnings.description: Using medications like Zegerid (proton pump inhibitors) can increase the chance of getting severe diarrhea.  This diarrhea is caused by an infection from a bacteria called clostridium difficle or C.Diff.  The infection is difficult to treat and can be life threatening. You are at a higher risk for C.Diff if you are currently or have recently been in a hospital.  You are also at higher risk if you are currently or have recently taken any antibiotic medication. If you develop significant diarrhea while taking Zegerid or after stopping it, let you doctor know right away.

If you develop significant diarrhea while taking Zegerid or after stopping it, let you doctor know right away.

risks_warnings.title: Broken bones
risks_warnings.description: There is an increased risk of developing weakened bones (osteoporosis) and broken bones (fractures) while taking medications like Zegerid (proton pump inhibitors).  It is believed that this happens because your stomach doesn't absorb calcium well while using this medication. Calcium is necessary for strong, healthy bones. In studies, people were more likely to get broken bones while using proton pump inhibitors when taking high doses and using them long-term (1 year or more). You are also at higher risk if you smoke or have other risk factors for osteoporosis.  The best way to prevent this side effect is to use the lowest dose of medication for the shortest period of time.  Taking a calcium supplement may or may not help prevent broken bones while using Zegerid.  However, if you need to take Zegerid long-term you should take a calcium supplement to be safe.  Be sure it's calcium citrate because it works the best when using a proton pump inhibitor.

risks_warnings.title: Low vitamin or mineral levels
risks_warnings.description: All proton pump inhibitor medications, including Zegerid, can cause low levels of blood magnesium or vitamin B12. This can happen with as little as 3 months of use but more commonly occurs after you've been using Zegerid for a year or more. Your doctor can do a blood test to see if you need to take a vitamin or mineral supplement.

risks_warnings.title: Weakens clopidogrel
risks_warnings.description: Zegerid can weaken the effects of the medication clopidogrel (Plavix).  Clopidogrel is used by people that have had a stroke or a coronary artery stent to prevent blood clots. Don't take Zegerid if you use clopidogrel.  If you feel you need Zegerid ask your doctor if any alternative medications for clopidogrel could work for you instead.

risks_warnings.title: Strengthens methotrexate
risks_warnings.description: Zegerid can interact with the medication methotrexate. It causes the levels of methotrexate to be higher in your blood and this can cause toxic side effects. If you take methotrexate, especially at high doses, avoid using Zegerid.

carousel_items: Short-term treatment of ulcers and acid reflux.

basics.benefits_moa: Famotidine is a type of antacid called an H2 blocker. It blocks the chemical histamine, which lowers acid production in your stomach. This treats heartburn and helps ulcers heal.
basics.bottom_line: Famotidine works well for heartburn but may not last as long or start working as quickly as other antacids.
downsides: Other antacids like Maalox, Tums, or Rolaids often start to work more quickly than Famotidine.
Medication like omeprazole (proton pump inhibitors) works better at healing and preventing stomach ulcers than medication like Famotidine (H2 blockers).
Can cause more serious side effects for people with kidney disease. Ask your doctor to give you a lower dose or choose a different option.

downsides_processed.orig: Other antacids like Maalox, Tums, or Rolaids often start to work more quickly than Famotidine.
Medication like omeprazole (proton pump inhibitors) works better at healing and preventing stomach ulcers than medication like Famotidine (H2 blockers).
Can cause more serious side effects for people with kidney disease. Ask your doctor to give you a lower dose or choose a different option.

upsides: Most people can take Famotidine without any noticeable day-to-day side effects.
Famotidine lasts longer than many other antacids like Maalox and Tums, and you only need to take it once or twice a day.
You can take it in combination with a quick-acting antacid (like Maalox or Tums) if you need relief right away.
Available as both a generic and over-the-counter option, so it's pretty affordable.
Few drug interactions.

risks_warnings.title: Increased side effects
risks_warnings.description: Because Famotidine is processed by the kidney it can cause some worrisome side effects for people with kidney problems. These include confusion, delirium, and a dangerous irregular heartbeat known as QT prolongation.   If you have kidney problems, you may need a different dose to prevent this increased risk for side effects.

risks_warnings.description: Famotidine can cause an allergic reaction.  The reaction might cause swelling of the throat, face, lips or tongue, difficulty breathing, or rash. If this happens to you stop taking Famotidine and get medical help right away. Do not take Famotidine if you have ever had an allergic reaction to similar medications like zantac or tagamet.
